Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates in Computer Vision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project represents a continuation of a Research Experience for Undergraduates site in Computer Vision which has operated successfully at the University of Central Florida for the past twenty-seven years. Approximately two hundred and seventy undergraduate students from sixty five institutions all over the country have participated in this program over the years. Each year, students will participate in a 12-week duration full-time Summer program. In past years, a substantial fraction of participants have been able to prepare a paper for submission to a refereed conference, have the paper accepted and then attend the conference to present the paper. The program will build these skills in participants: ability to write complex computer programs; ability to communicate orally about a research problem; ability to present one's project via technology such as PowerPoint; ability to do a poster presentation about the project, and answer questions; ability to think about computer vision issues in real life problems; ability to do initial reading of a research paper in computer vision; ability to contribute to discussion of a vision problem; and ability to embark on applying to graduate school.


The research emphasizes development of new algorithms for solving scientific problems in visual geo-localization and segmentation, object detection, multi-target tracking, activity and event recognition. It advances both theory and practice; in mathematical modeling and analysis of difficult vision problems and developing algorithms, while at the same time building real systems for demonstrating those solutions in real life situations. The educational model employed by this site includes round-the-clock mentoring by a team that includes a professor and a graduate student; a streamlined short course that lets participants start their research projects sooner; daily meetings with mentors to plan activities throughout the day; training in MatLab for quick turnaround of research ideas. Participants take the short course on fundamentals of computer vision, match themselves to a project topic that they most desire, and spend sufficient time in focused research. Some possible research projects include: Location-Aware Semantic Segmentation; Multi-target Tracking with Social Behavior, Model, Human Action Recognition etc. After summer, students then can opt for follow-through over the year by working with the professors to write a technical report on their project, to prepare for the GREs and to apply to graduate programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intellectual Merits for this project include the development of new computer vision algorithms for a variety of applications. The project was designed to conduct mathematical modeling and analysis of difficult vision problems, while at the same time building real systems for demonstrating those solutions in real life situations.

The Broader Impacts include contributing to preparing a work-force of young scientists in order to maintain American strategic leadership in Science and Engineering. This involves providing opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduates, most being from predominantly undergraduate institutions, to spend a summer in training with a highly successful research group.

This REU site solicits applications from sophomore, junior, and senior undergraduates in computer science, computer engineering and related fields, who are U.S. citizens or U.S. permanent residents, with a GPA of 3.0 or above. Thirty students were selected to participate during the three-year period, 10 students during each of the summers of 2015, 2016 and 2017. Of these 30, 11 were from UCF, AZ, AL, FL, IL, KY, LA, MA, NC, NV, NY, OH, RI, TN, TX. The 30 students were composed of 12 females (of which 2 were Hispanic), and 18 males (of which 2 were African American, and 4 were Hispanic).

During each cohort's summer, the ten participants attended a short course on computer vision during the first two weeks. The following topics were covered: Computer Vision Introduction, Filtering, Edge Detection, Python and Keras Tutorial, Optical Flow, Boosting and SVM, Introduction to Medical Imaging, Algorithms and Methods for Computational Radiology, Neural Networks, Deep Learning, Basics of human vision, Visual attention and Egocentric vision. Following that, graduate students, Post Docs and professors presented project topic choices, and during the next two days, each participant made a short list of their preferred topics and discussed these with the graduate mentors and professors. This process led to a final choice of topic. The students then worked full time on their individual research projects during the remaining 9 weeks of the summer.

Each participant met with the supervising group composed of the professors and relevant graduate students to give a weekly report. During this reporting session, the participant conducted a 20-minute powerpoint presentation. These presentations are available on the REU website. Further, the participant met daily with one (or more) of the members from the supervising group. In addition to the weekly presentations, participants presented their mid-summer results to a broader group of professors, graduate student mentors, and other participants and some guests.

Each cohort attended a PhD student's proposal presentation, and another PhD student's disseration defense. To strengthen writing skills, participants were given guidance on how to write their project research report, which was due on their final day.

The summer activities for each cohort included three field trips to local companies (Harris Corporation, Lockheed Martin, and Sighthound) that deploy computer vision. Each trip's agenda included a corporate tour, several presentations and demos by the host company, and each student making a five-minute presentation about their own REU project.

The cohorts attended a four-hour long workshop in late July on Graduate School Preparation that covered the following topics: Why Graduate School? UCF CS Graduate Programs, How to maximize one's chances of getting into a Ph.D. program, and Applying for Fellowships (presentations by recent winners of NSF Fellowships).

Planned social events provided opportunities to conduct mentoring about other aspects of life. These included several lunches with the project leaders at local restaurants. Additionally, a mid-summer daylong social on a Saturday at Blue Springs State Park was held in partnership with another REU site at UCF. On the final evening, participants attended a banquet dinner.

Students produced a poster of their research accomplishments, and presented it at the end of the summer. The research activities resulted in advancements in algorithms for motion tracking, for object and activity recognition, for medical image segmentation and case identification, and egocentric vision. Several students published their research in high impact venues in the months after the summer training. Many have proceeded to enter studies towards advanced degrees.
